title: Write VISION.md
description:
## Required Reading
- .claude/rules/vision-format.md (format rule)
- .claude/rules/documentation-standards.md (writing style)
- .claude/rules/promt.md (Cupboard/Table design brief)
- Bootstrap description in .claude/commands/bootstrap.md

## Files to Create
- docs/VISION.md

## Requirements

Write VISION.md per vision-format rule. Cobbler is a CLI tool that orchestrates AI coding agents to plan and execute software development work. It connects to a crumbs cupboard (work item storage) and coordinates agents through four self-* capabilities drawn from autogenic systems.

Cobbler replaces the prototype bash scripts (scripts/make-work.sh and scripts/do-work.sh) with a proper Go tool that has direct cupboard access via the crumbs Go module, structured prompt templates, and a real agent loop.

The command set uses shoemaking metaphors mapped to autogenic self-* capabilities:

| Self-capability | Command | Shoemaking | What it does |
|----------------|---------|-----------|-------------|
| Self-orienting | cobbler measure | Measure the foot | Assess project state, propose tasks |
| Self-programming | cobbler stitch | Elves sew the shoes | Execute work via AI agents |
| Self-reflecting | cobbler inspect / cobbler mend | Check the seams / repair the sole | Evaluate output, fix issues |
| Self-architecting | cobbler pattern | Draft the template | Propose design and structural changes |

Sections to write:
1. Executive Summary: cobbler orchestrates AI agents for software development through four self-* capabilities (self-orienting, self-programming, self-reflecting, self-architecting). It is not a task tracker, IDE plugin, or CI system.
2. Introduction: context (AI agents need coordination; autogenic systems that can orient, program, reflect, and architect themselves). Problem (manual agent orchestration is slow and error-prone; prototype bash scripts do not scale). What cobbler does (connects to crumbs cupboard, measures the work, stitches it via agents, inspects results, mends failures, and patterns new designs).
3. Why this project: fills the gap between task storage (crumbs) and agent execution. Graduates prototype scripts (make-work.sh, do-work.sh) into a real tool. Leverages existing cupboard interfaces via Go module import.
4. Planning and Implementation: success criteria (agents complete doc and code tasks autonomously via cobbler stitch), phases table (01.0 stitch docs, 02.0 stitch code, 03.0 measure, 04.0 inspect/mend/pattern), risks table.
5. What This Is NOT: not a task tracker (use crumbs), not an IDE plugin, not a CI system, not fully autonomous (humans approve measure output before stitch executes).

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] All required sections per vision-format present
- [ ] Autogenic self-* capabilities and command mapping explained
- [ ] Origin story: replaces make-work.sh and do-work.sh prototype scripts
- [ ] Style follows documentation-standards (active voice, no forbidden terms, royal we)
- [ ] File saved as docs/VISION.md

title: Write ARCHITECTURE.md
description:
## Required Reading
- docs/VISION.md (written in prior issue)
- .claude/rules/architecture-format.md (format rule)
- .claude/rules/documentation-standards.md (writing style)
- .claude/rules/promt.md (Cupboard/Table design brief)
- Crumbs docs: /Users/petardjukic/WORKSPACE/crumbs/docs/ARCHITECTURE.md (cupboard/table interfaces)
- Crumbs PRDs: /Users/petardjukic/WORKSPACE/crumbs/docs/product-requirements/ (interface contracts)

## Files to Create
- docs/ARCHITECTURE.md

## Requirements

Write ARCHITECTURE.md per architecture-format rule. Describe how cobbler is built: components, interfaces, data flow, and design decisions. Use the autogenic framing from VISION.md.

Cobbler replaces prototype scripts (scripts/make-work.sh → measure, scripts/do-work.sh → stitch) with a Go tool.

Commands map to self-* capabilities:

| Self-capability | Command | What it does |
|----------------|---------|-------------|
| Self-orienting | cobbler measure | Assess project state, propose tasks |
| Self-programming | cobbler stitch | Execute work via AI agents |
| Self-reflecting | cobbler inspect / cobbler mend | Evaluate output, fix issues |
| Self-architecting | cobbler pattern | Propose design changes |

Sections to write:
1. System Overview: cobbler connects to crumbs cupboard (imported as Go module), coordinates AI agents to measure, stitch, inspect, mend, and pattern. Lifecycle of a work item through cobbler (ready → claimed → prompt built → agent executes → quality gate → closed). Coordination pattern: pull-based (cobbler queries cupboard for ready crumbs).
2. Main interfaces: Cupboard integration (import crumbs Go module, Cupboard.GetTable(name).Get/Set pattern), Agent interface (Run method, Tool interface), Executor interface (claim, execute, close loop).
3. System Components: CLI (cobra, commands: measure, stitch, inspect, mend, pattern), Config (viper), Measure (reads docs/roadmap/cupboard, proposes crumbs - replaces make-work.sh), Executor/Stitch (picks up and implements work - replaces do-work.sh), Agent (LLM abstraction, Claude impl via anthropic-sdk-go), Prompt Builder (templates for doc/code tasks), Crumbs Client (thin wrapper around imported crumbs Go module).
4. Design Decisions: (a) import crumbs as Go module not CLI wrapper, (b) agent interface for provider abstraction - Claude only first, (c) prompt templates in internal/prompt not embedded, (d) commands named after shoemaking terms mapped to autogenic self-* capabilities.
5. Technology Choices: Go, cobra, viper, crumbs module (github.com/petar-djukic/crumbs), anthropic-sdk-go.
6. Project Structure: cmd/cobbler/, pkg/ (agent, planner, executor, crumbs), internal/ (prompt, config, claude).
7. Implementation Status: phase 01.0 focus is cobbler stitch --docs.

## Design Decisions
- Cupboard accessed via imported Go module (github.com/petar-djukic/crumbs)
- Agent interface allows swapping LLM providers; start with Claude via anthropic-sdk-go
- Prompt templates stored in internal/prompt/ as Go templates or embedded strings
- Command names from shoemaking trade: measure, stitch, inspect, mend, pattern
- Each command maps 1:1 to an autogenic self-* capability

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] All required sections per architecture-format present
- [ ] Components and interfaces described with enough detail for PRD authors
- [ ] Command set (measure, stitch, inspect, mend, pattern) documented with self-* mapping
- [ ] Design decisions numbered with rationale
- [ ] Technology choices table present
- [ ] Project structure directory tree present
- [ ] Style follows documentation-standards
- [ ] File saved as docs/ARCHITECTURE.md

title: Write ROADMAP.yaml
description:
## Required Reading
- docs/VISION.md (written in prior issue)
- .claude/rules/use-case-format.md (release numbering scheme)

## Files to Create
- docs/ROADMAP.yaml

## Requirements

Write ROADMAP.yaml as a YAML file defining the release schedule and use case status for cobbler.

Commands use shoemaking terms mapped to autogenic self-* capabilities:
- measure (self-orienting): assess state, propose tasks
- stitch (self-programming): execute work via agents
- inspect (self-reflecting): show project state
- mend (self-reflecting): fix tests and lint
- pattern (self-architecting): propose design changes

Releases:
- 00.0: Cross-release milestones (spans multiple releases)
- 01.0: Core stitch (docs) - cobbler stitch --docs working end-to-end
  - Use cases: cupboard connection, doc task execution, agent loop
- 02.0: Core stitch (code) - cobbler stitch --code working
  - Use cases: code task execution, quality gates (test, lint)
- 03.0: Measure - cobbler measure working (replaces make-work.sh)
  - Use cases: project analysis, work proposal, crumb creation
- 04.0: Inspect, mend, and pattern - remaining self-* capabilities
  - Use cases: project state display, test/lint fix loop, design proposals
- 99.0: Unscheduled

Each release entry should include: focus description, list of use cases with status (planned/in-progress/done), and deliverables.

## Acceptance Criteria
- [ ] YAML is valid and parseable
- [ ] All releases listed with focus, use cases, and deliverables
- [ ] Commands use revised names (measure, stitch, inspect, mend, pattern)
- [ ] Release numbering matches use-case-format convention (NN.N)
- [ ] File saved as docs/ROADMAP.yaml
